column2: Why not include accommodation and food services as an industry, which has a high smoking rate?

the age group you choose probably is experiencing some tobacco related health problems at that point in their life. can you examine younger ages who also smoke but haven't accrued the health complications yet?
you talk abou "tobacco use". Do you differentiate between smoking and non-combustible?
you talk abou "tobacco use". Do you differentiate between smoking and non-combustible?
column5: The claims don't do a great job of separating out different types of tobacco product use, but there is some information on different types of use. I believe we use any type of tobacco product use as any type of tobacco product use could conceivably be treated with counseling, for example.

column2: What part of the PSL is attributable to smoking related health issues?
column5: We're primarily study if PSL impacts counseling or prescription fills. PSL could increase doctor visits for example, which could lead to more opportunities for smoking cessation treatment. We don't see evidence of any increase, though, as Kevin just explained.

column2: Do you think this is impacted by the family dr. shortage?
Hi Mike, Please, can you refer me to the JHR paper on non-parallel trends? Thanks
column5: Yes, here is the link for that paper: https://jhr.uwpress.org/content/early/2020/05/04/jhr.57.4.1017-9124R2.

column2: do you find small effects because employees are quitting by using nicotine pouches, or vaping products, as opposed to cessation with a Healthcare provider? could you get at this descriptively with another dataset?
